column1:
Anti-Asian violence shows folly of defunding police movement

Tom Elias

USA Today

2021-03-21

There’s an old saying about traditions: Abandon a tradition it tells us and you will soon learn why it became one.

That’s what California cities are learning today as city councils around the state have acted on the urging of Black Lives Matter protesters and diverted portions of their former police budgets to social action causes in previously underserved neighborhoods.

But the spate of anti-Asian violence now playing out in California communities as disparate as Sacramento San Jose Los Angeles San Leandro and Orange County dramatically shows this was folly.

The logical police response to on-street attacks ought to be more foot and squad car patrols but that’s not happening in most places despite the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So they continue showing no signs of abating.

Before the coronavirus pandemic this was not a big problem. Hate crimes against Asians were relatively few and far between. But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the “Chinese virus.”

Atlanta shootings: Racism clearly drove Atlanta shootings. It also fuels sexual exploitation of Asian women.

Around California these crimes have far more than doubled over the last year but no one can put a precise number on them. In San Francisco they have at least tripled. In Los Angeles there have been more than twice as many this year as a year ago. But official numbers are likely far lower than in real life partly because police don’t do much about the attacks.

Not even 700-person rallies decrying the attacks like one the other day in San Jose can stop them.

The head of a Southern California group called Asian-Americans Advancing Justice told one reporter many such crimes go unreported because of language problems immigrants unable to communicate with police. Plus she said “When victims … come forward having the police say nothing can be done discourages other victims from relying on police.”

Some immigrant advocates also say Korean-Americans and other Asian groups are perceiving new bias among police officers perhaps caused by the Trump rhetoric.

Keith Ellison and Jonathan Greenblatt: Stand together to fight anti-Asian hate. We all have a stake in a more inclusive America.

But the mere presence of cops on street patrol could have stopped one early March assault on an elderly Asian man who was seated in a Nob Hill laundromat in San Francisco when at attacker ambushed him. Police presence probably would have spared the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee an 84-year-old Thai-American beaten to death in broad daylight also in San Francisco.

Neither of their assailants has been identified like most others conducting the current spate of attacks.

There are also less violent but still threatening incidents. One Asian-American woman stopped at a red light the other day in Fresno and a man in the next car signaled she should roll down her window. When she did he shouted “Get out of my country — that’s an order.” After pausing he reportedly added “I’ll kill you.”

All this is a demonstration that even a “model minority” noted for high achievement and founding large and successful businesses of many types can suddenly be targeted especially when national leaders become loose-lipped about their own prejudices.

It also shows that not only California but the entire nation needs effective policing to protect minorities who have no way to know when they might be victimized even if their particular ethnic group enjoys generally high public esteem.

Because bigots have always picked on those they see as weak this is especially important for elderly and frail individuals.

Yes the pandemic appears to have originated in or near the Chinese city of Wuhan. But there is no evidence it was deliberately perpetrated on the world. The claim that it was amounts to a blood libel against Chinese individuals who would have been thousands of miles away even if deeds like this had been done.

Because most others have difficulty discerning Asians’ native nationalities simply from their appearance all Asian-Americans are now at serious risk especially if they don’t look strong a la the Los Angeles Angels’ 6-foot 4-inch 210 pound Shohei Otani.

Police are their only assured protection from random violence and bigotry when they leave their homes. And the fewer cops on the street the more danger for them. Which is just one reason it makes little sense to defund police as Americans are now discovering.

column3: COVID-19/coronavirus/pandemic (Triggering anti-Asian hate)
column4: The article discusses that the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes began around the time Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus as the “Chinese virus.” ("But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the 'Chinese virus.'")
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "COVID-19/coronavirus/pandemic (Triggering anti-Asian hate)" is a reasonably good fit for this article, but it's not a perfect match. Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is highly relevant to the article. The piece explicitly mentions the connection between the coronavirus pandemic and the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. The article states, "But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the 'Chinese virus.'" This directly links the pandemic to the increase in anti-Asian violence.

2. Specificity: The concept is at an appropriate level of specificity. It captures the broad idea of the pandemic triggering anti-Asian hate, which is a key theme in the article. However, the article goes into more specific details about police defunding and its impact on protecting Asian Americans, which isn't captured by this concept alone.

3. Coverage: While the concept covers an important aspect of the article, it doesn't encompass all of its main points. The article spends significant time discussing the defunding of police and its negative impact on protecting Asian Americans from hate crimes. This aspect isn't directly related to the chosen concept.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects a key point in the article – that the pandemic, particularly when framed as the "Chinese virus," triggered an increase in anti-Asian hate. However, it doesn't capture the article's main argument about the need for police presence to protect Asian Americans.

5. Insight: The concept provides some insight into the root cause of the increased anti-Asian violence discussed in the article. However, it doesn't capture the article's main argument about the importance of police funding and presence in protecting minority communities.

The chosen concept is relevant and accurate for a portion of the article, but it doesn't fully represent the main argument or focus of the piece. The article uses the pandemic-triggered hate as a starting point but then pivots to discuss the importance of police presence and the folly of defunding the police in light of these hate crimes. A concept that better captures the article's main point might be something related to law enforcement's role in protecting minorities from hate crimes.

</reasoning>

<score>
6
</score>
</evaluation>

column3: Types of Anti-Asian hate/Individual-level racism/Stereotype B/China/Chinese/Asian virus”/“Kung flu/plague/Ramen noodle flu
column4: The article mentions the phrase “Chinese virus,” which is a stereotype that contributes to individual-level racism against Asians. ("...Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the 'Chinese virus.'")
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "Types of Anti-Asian hate/Individual-level racism/Stereotype B/China/Chinese/Asian virus"/"Kung flu/plague/Ramen noodle flu" is relevant to the article, but its fit is not as strong or comprehensive as it could be. Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it directly mentions the phrase "Chinese virus" attributed to Donald Trump. This stereotype is presented as a catalyst for the increase in anti-Asian hate crimes. However, this is not the main focus of the article.

2. Specificity: The chosen concept is quite specific, which is both a strength and a weakness. It accurately pinpoints a key term mentioned in the article, but it may be too narrow to capture the broader themes discussed.

3. Coverage: The concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. While the "Chinese virus" phrase is mentioned as a turning point, the article primarily focuses on the consequences of defunding police and its impact on anti-Asian violence.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects the information presented in the article regarding the use of the term "Chinese virus." However, it doesn't capture the article's main argument about police defunding and its effects on anti-Asian hate crimes.

5. Insight: The concept provides some insight into one factor contributing to anti-Asian hate, but it doesn't offer much depth in understanding the article's primary message about police presence and protection of minorities.

The article touches on various themes that could be better represented by other concepts from the tree, such as:
- "Types of Anti-Asian hate/Individual-level racism/Physical attack/violence/Anti-Asian hate crimes"
- "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate/Law enforcement agency/Local police/Useless law enforcement"
- "Impacts of Anti-Asian hate on Asian Americans/Behavioral/Not reporting/confronting anti-Asian hate incidents"

These concepts would more comprehensively capture the article's focus on the increase in anti-Asian hate crimes, the role of police in preventing such crimes, and the challenges in reporting and addressing these incidents.

While the chosen concept is relevant and accurate for a specific part of the article, it fails to represent the main arguments and broader context presented by the author.
</reasoning>

<score>
5
</score>
</evaluation>

column1:
Anti-Asian violence shows folly of defunding police movement

Tom Elias

USA Today

2021-03-21

There’s an old saying about traditions: Abandon a tradition it tells us and you will soon learn why it became one.

That’s what California cities are learning today as city councils around the state have acted on the urging of Black Lives Matter protesters and diverted portions of their former police budgets to social action causes in previously underserved neighborhoods.

But the spate of anti-Asian violence now playing out in California communities as disparate as Sacramento San Jose Los Angeles San Leandro and Orange County dramatically shows this was folly.

The logical police response to on-street attacks ought to be more foot and squad car patrols but that’s not happening in most places despite the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So they continue showing no signs of abating.

Before the coronavirus pandemic this was not a big problem. Hate crimes against Asians were relatively few and far between. But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the “Chinese virus.”

Atlanta shootings: Racism clearly drove Atlanta shootings. It also fuels sexual exploitation of Asian women.

Around California these crimes have far more than doubled over the last year but no one can put a precise number on them. In San Francisco they have at least tripled. In Los Angeles there have been more than twice as many this year as a year ago. But official numbers are likely far lower than in real life partly because police don’t do much about the attacks.

Not even 700-person rallies decrying the attacks like one the other day in San Jose can stop them.

The head of a Southern California group called Asian-Americans Advancing Justice told one reporter many such crimes go unreported because of language problems immigrants unable to communicate with police. Plus she said “When victims … come forward having the police say nothing can be done discourages other victims from relying on police.”

Some immigrant advocates also say Korean-Americans and other Asian groups are perceiving new bias among police officers perhaps caused by the Trump rhetoric.

Keith Ellison and Jonathan Greenblatt: Stand together to fight anti-Asian hate. We all have a stake in a more inclusive America.

But the mere presence of cops on street patrol could have stopped one early March assault on an elderly Asian man who was seated in a Nob Hill laundromat in San Francisco when at attacker ambushed him. Police presence probably would have spared the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee an 84-year-old Thai-American beaten to death in broad daylight also in San Francisco.

Neither of their assailants has been identified like most others conducting the current spate of attacks.

There are also less violent but still threatening incidents. One Asian-American woman stopped at a red light the other day in Fresno and a man in the next car signaled she should roll down her window. When she did he shouted “Get out of my country — that’s an order.” After pausing he reportedly added “I’ll kill you.”

All this is a demonstration that even a “model minority” noted for high achievement and founding large and successful businesses of many types can suddenly be targeted especially when national leaders become loose-lipped about their own prejudices.

It also shows that not only California but the entire nation needs effective policing to protect minorities who have no way to know when they might be victimized even if their particular ethnic group enjoys generally high public esteem.

Because bigots have always picked on those they see as weak this is especially important for elderly and frail individuals.

Yes the pandemic appears to have originated in or near the Chinese city of Wuhan. But there is no evidence it was deliberately perpetrated on the world. The claim that it was amounts to a blood libel against Chinese individuals who would have been thousands of miles away even if deeds like this had been done.

Because most others have difficulty discerning Asians’ native nationalities simply from their appearance all Asian-Americans are now at serious risk especially if they don’t look strong a la the Los Angeles Angels’ 6-foot 4-inch 210 pound Shohei Otani.

Police are their only assured protection from random violence and bigotry when they leave their homes. And the fewer cops on the street the more danger for them. Which is just one reason it makes little sense to defund police as Americans are now discovering.

Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it discusses the ineffectiveness of police in addressing anti-Asian hate crimes. However, the article's main focus is on the consequences of defunding the police rather than specifically on police not taking reports.

2. Specificity: The chosen concept is quite specific, which is good. However, it may be too narrow for the broader issues discussed in the article. The article talks about various aspects of police ineffectiveness, not just failing to take reports.

3. Coverage: The concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. While the article does mention that police often don't do much about the attacks, it also discusses other aspects such as the need for more police presence, the impact of defunding, and the broader context of anti-Asian violence.

4. Accuracy: The concept is accurate in that it reflects a point made in the article. The explanation cites a relevant quote: "When victims … come forward having the police say nothing can be done discourages other victims from relying on police." However, this is not the main focus of the article.

5. Insight: The concept provides some insight into one aspect of the problem discussed in the article, but it doesn't capture the article's main argument about the negative consequences of defunding the police.

The article primarily argues that defunding the police has led to increased vulnerability for Asian Americans. It suggests that more police presence could prevent attacks, rather than focusing on police not taking reports. For example, the article states, "The logical police response to on-street attacks ought to be more foot and squad car patrols, but that's not happening in most places despite the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes."

A more fitting concept might be something that encompasses the broader theme of police defunding and its impact on minority protection, or the need for effective policing to protect vulnerable communities.

While the chosen concept is not incorrect, it doesn't fully capture the main thrust of the article or its broader implications.

It also shows that not only California but the entire nation needs effective policing to protect minorities who have no way to know when they might be victimized even if their particular ethnic group enjoys generally high public esteem.

Because bigots have always picked on those they see as weak this is especially important for elderly and frail individuals.

Yes the pandemic appears to have originated in or near the Chinese city of Wuhan. But there is no evidence it was deliberately perpetrated on the world. The claim that it was amounts to a blood libel against Chinese individuals who would have been thousands of miles away even if deeds like this had been done.

Because most others have difficulty discerning Asians’ native nationalities simply from their appearance all Asian-Americans are now at serious risk especially if they don’t look strong a la the Los Angeles Angels’ 6-foot 4-inch 210 pound Shohei Otani.

Police are their only assured protection from random violence and bigotry when they leave their homes. And the fewer cops on the street the more danger for them. Which is just one reason it makes little sense to defund police as Americans are now discovering.

column4: The article suggests that Donald Trump's rhetoric initiated a surge in anti-Asian hate. ("But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the 'Chinese virus.'")

The chosen concept "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate/Individuals/Non-Asians/Donald Trump/Initiated anti-Asian hate and racism" fits the article to a moderate degree, but there are some limitations to consider:

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it does mention Donald Trump's role in the increase of anti-Asian hate crimes. The article states, "But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the 'Chinese virus.'" This directly relates to the chosen concept.

2. Specificity: The concept is quite specific, which is both a strength and a weakness. It accurately pinpoints Trump's role in initiating anti-Asian hate, but it may be too narrow given the broader scope of the article.

3. Coverage: The concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. While Trump's role is mentioned, it is not the main focus. The article primarily discusses the increase in anti-Asian violence, the inadequacy of police response, and the consequences of defunding the police.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects the information presented in the article regarding Trump's role. However, it doesn't capture the article's main argument about the folly of defunding the police in light of increased anti-Asian violence.

5. Insight: The concept provides some insight into one factor contributing to the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes, but it doesn't capture the article's central thesis about the need for effective policing to protect minorities.

The chosen concept, while relevant, represents only a small part of the article's content. The article's main focus is on the consequences of defunding the police and the need for increased police presence to protect Asian Americans from hate crimes. It touches on Trump's role briefly, but this is not the central theme.

The article spends more time discussing the increase in anti-Asian hate crimes, specific examples of these crimes, and the argument that reducing police funding has left Asian Americans more vulnerable. For example, the article states, "Police are their only assured protection from random violence and bigotry when they leave their homes. And the fewer cops on the street, the more danger for them. Which is just one reason it makes little sense to defund police, as Americans are now discovering."

A concept that better captures the main thrust of the article might be something related to law enforcement's role in protecting minorities or the consequences of defunding the police in the face of rising hate crimes.

column1:
Anti-Asian violence shows folly of defunding police movement

Tom Elias

USA Today

2021-03-21

There’s an old saying about traditions: Abandon a tradition it tells us and you will soon learn why it became one.

That’s what California cities are learning today as city councils around the state have acted on the urging of Black Lives Matter protesters and diverted portions of their former police budgets to social action causes in previously underserved neighborhoods.

But the spate of anti-Asian violence now playing out in California communities as disparate as Sacramento San Jose Los Angeles San Leandro and Orange County dramatically shows this was folly.

The logical police response to on-street attacks ought to be more foot and squad car patrols but that’s not happening in most places despite the rise in anti-Asian hate crimes. So they continue showing no signs of abating.

Before the coronavirus pandemic this was not a big problem. Hate crimes against Asians were relatively few and far between. But a huge upswing began just about the time ex-President Donald Trump dubbed the coronavirus plague the “Chinese virus.”

Atlanta shootings: Racism clearly drove Atlanta shootings. It also fuels sexual exploitation of Asian women.

Around California these crimes have far more than doubled over the last year but no one can put a precise number on them. In San Francisco they have at least tripled. In Los Angeles there have been more than twice as many this year as a year ago. But official numbers are likely far lower than in real life partly because police don’t do much about the attacks.

Not even 700-person rallies decrying the attacks like one the other day in San Jose can stop them.

The head of a Southern California group called Asian-Americans Advancing Justice told one reporter many such crimes go unreported because of language problems immigrants unable to communicate with police. Plus she said “When victims … come forward having the police say nothing can be done discourages other victims from relying on police.”

Some immigrant advocates also say Korean-Americans and other Asian groups are perceiving new bias among police officers perhaps caused by the Trump rhetoric.

Keith Ellison and Jonathan Greenblatt: Stand together to fight anti-Asian hate. We all have a stake in a more inclusive America.

But the mere presence of cops on street patrol could have stopped one early March assault on an elderly Asian man who was seated in a Nob Hill laundromat in San Francisco when at attacker ambushed him. Police presence probably would have spared the death of Vicha Ratanapakdee an 84-year-old Thai-American beaten to death in broad daylight also in San Francisco.

Neither of their assailants has been identified like most others conducting the current spate of attacks.

There are also less violent but still threatening incidents. One Asian-American woman stopped at a red light the other day in Fresno and a man in the next car signaled she should roll down her window. When she did he shouted “Get out of my country — that’s an order.” After pausing he reportedly added “I’ll kill you.”

All this is a demonstration that even a “model minority” noted for high achievement and founding large and successful businesses of many types can suddenly be targeted especially when national leaders become loose-lipped about their own prejudices.

It also shows that not only California but the entire nation needs effective policing to protect minorities who have no way to know when they might be victimized even if their particular ethnic group enjoys generally high public esteem.

Because bigots have always picked on those they see as weak this is especially important for elderly and frail individuals.

Yes the pandemic appears to have originated in or near the Chinese city of Wuhan. But there is no evidence it was deliberately perpetrated on the world. The claim that it was amounts to a blood libel against Chinese individuals who would have been thousands of miles away even if deeds like this had been done.

Because most others have difficulty discerning Asians’ native nationalities simply from their appearance all Asian-Americans are now at serious risk especially if they don’t look strong a la the Los Angeles Angels’ 6-foot 4-inch 210 pound Shohei Otani.

Police are their only assured protection from random violence and bigotry when they leave their homes. And the fewer cops on the street the more danger for them. Which is just one reason it makes little sense to defund police as Americans are now discovering.

1. Relevance: The concept is somewhat relevant to the article's theme, as the article discusses the need for protection of Asian Americans from hate crimes. However, the article focuses more on the role of police in providing this protection, rather than on Asian Americans taking proactive measures themselves.

2. Specificity: The chosen concept is quite specific, focusing on behavioral impacts and proactive self-defense. While this level of specificity could be appropriate if the article discussed such measures, it doesn't. The article instead emphasizes the need for increased police presence and patrols.

3. Coverage: The concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. The article primarily discusses the increase in anti-Asian hate crimes, the ineffectiveness of reduced police budgets, and the need for more police presence. It doesn't mention Asian Americans taking proactive self-defense measures.

4. Accuracy: The concept is not particularly accurate in representing the article's content. The article doesn't discuss Asian Americans engaging in proactive self-defense or protection. Instead, it argues that police are the "only assured protection" for Asian Americans.

5. Insight: While the concept could provide insight into potential responses to anti-Asian hate, it doesn't align well with the article's main argument, which is about the importance of police presence in preventing hate crimes.

The explanation provided for choosing this concept states that "The article argues for increased police presence as a means to protect Asian Americans from random acts of violence." This is accurate, but it actually points to why the chosen concept is not a good fit. The article is indeed about protection, but it's specifically about protection provided by law enforcement, not proactive self-defense by Asian Americans themselves.

A more fitting concept from the tree might be "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate/Law enforcement agency/Local police (e.g., city- and state-level)" or even "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate/Government officers/City/Stop Anti-Asian hate/Support Asian Americans/Increasing patrols". These concepts would better capture the article's emphasis on the role of police and increased patrols in protecting Asian Americans from hate crimes.

column1:
After Georgia Attacks Asian Americans Demand Serious Action on Bias

Eligon John, Fuller Thomas, Cowan Jill

New York Times

2021-03-18

Police officers mingle with demonstrators at a ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)
Video clips of disturbing attacks on the street. Insults hurled by politicians. Derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses.
For most of the last year, Asian Americans have sounded the alarm over the rising discrimination they have experienced and witnessed fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump and other public officials. Celebrities, activists, and influencers on social media have implored people to stop the hate against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders.
Then came the fatal shootings in Georgia of eight people, six of them women of Asian descent.
Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the carnage has evoked another emotion among some Asian Americans: anger over the country’s long-standing failure to take discrimination against them seriously.
Some scholars and activists said Tuesday’s massacre was unsurprising after public officials and popular culture have for years downplayed the dangers of bias and stereotypes against Asians.
Although Asian Americans, like other minority groups, have endured a long history of deadly violence, the threats and discrimination they continue to face are often trivialized as harmless insults. In many cases, some said, people are reluctant to even acknowledge that attacks against Asian Americans could be racially motivated, as happened Wednesday when a law enforcement official in Georgia seemed to dismiss racial animus as a motive in the shootings.
Instead, he said the suspect, Robert Aaron Long, who is white, was having “a really bad day” and cited Long’s statement that he was driven by a sex addiction and not racial bias.
Even when anti-Asian violence is acknowledged, experts say it is sometimes casually dismissed as an isolated episode rather than a core part of the Asian American story.
“There’s a tendency to not believe that violence against Asian Americans is real,” said Angela Hsu, 52, a lawyer in suburban Atlanta. “It’s almost like you need something really, really jarring to make people believe that there is discrimination against Asian Americans.”
Without a deeper, widespread understanding of, or belief in the dangers that Asian Americans face, it’s difficult for activists to marshal a concerted national push — in law enforcement, the media, and the public — to fight anti-Asian racism, activists say.
They tend to be invisible to much of society, which only furthers a widespread dismissal of anti-Asian violence, said Chris J. Lee, 33, a founder of Plan A Magazine, an online journal focused on Asian American culture and politics.
“The types of people who get killed, like people who work at massage parlors, elderly Asians picking up cans for a living — none of us really know these people,” he said.
The marginalization of Asian Americans has deep roots.
Chinese immigrants who built railways and mined gold in the 19th century were shunted into Chinatowns in San Francisco and other cities, redlined by financial institutions and often left to fend for themselves.
Further immigration from China was restricted by the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the first immigration law targeting working-class immigrants from a specific country. It was followed in 1917 by the most restrictive immigration law in the nation’s history, the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, which blocked immigrants from Istanbul all the way to Jakarta and beyond, nearly eliminating all arrivals from some of the most populous areas of the planet — the South Asian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.
Japanese residents in the United States were for decades kept out of white neighborhoods through covenants written into real estate deeds; tens of thousands of American citizens of Japanese descent were incarcerated in internment camps during World War II.
When immigration laws were liberalized in the 1960s, immigrants from Asia were allowed into the U.S. in unprecedented numbers. 
Asian ethnic groups, though distinct from one another, have at times been lumped together under the umbrella of an Asian American identity. But the anti-Asian violence that has come during the pandemic seems to have solidified a greater sense of solidarity among a group that is diverse in income, religion, and culture, said Will Lex Ham, an actor who has helped lead a campaign of awareness of violence against Asians.
“As long as we share the same physical features, we are being treated the same in this country,” Ham said.
In the wake of attacks on older people in Asian neighborhoods in California, some community leaders have demanded an increased police presence. Others have said that simply adding law enforcement officers was not a solution.
Some are pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to appoint an Asian American to be California’s attorney general.
An Asian American as the state’s top law enforcement official is needed to build trust “particularly when it comes to what have been strained relationships between law enforcement and immigrant communities and communities of color,” David Chiu, a member of the California state Assembly, said during a news conference Wednesday.
In the Atlanta area, where the Asian community has grown in recent years and become more politically influential, the murders have reignited anxieties that may have been subsiding for some people as an end to the pandemic is in sight. When the pandemic began, Hsu, the lawyer, said she almost expected that people would hurl insults at her because she is Chinese American. In recent weeks, she had let her guard down, she said.
“We’re coming out of the pandemic, there’s a new president, we’re not hearing ‘Kung Flu’ and ‘China Virus’ every other word,” she said, referring to some of the derogatory terms that Trump used for the coronavirus. “I was really lured into thinking it’s sort of safe to go outside again.” 
Now she is back on high alert.
Suraiya Sharker, a community organizer with the Atlanta chapter of the National Asian Pacific American Women’s Forum, said that after the shootings, she received calls from several members of her organization who were in tears.
Sharker, 22, is particularly worried about her parents, who moved to the United States from Bangladesh when she was 4, because they are of the demographic particularly vulnerable to attacks. As first-generation immigrants, their English is not perfect. They work in a fast-food restaurant in suburban Atlanta where Sharker said a customer once threatened her father in a disagreement over the bill and customers have refused to be served by her mother because she wears a hijab.
But as much as she and other Asian Americans are more cautious now, they are also more energized, she said.
“This,” she said, “has been an awakening for a lot of folks to say ‘Enough is enough.’”

A woman leaves flowers at a memorial outside of Gold Spa in Atlanta following the mass shooting there, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Lynsey Weatherspoon/The New York Times)

Brittany Tabora and Ina Padua participate in a demonstration against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Shuran Huang/The New York Times)

Members of a progressive youth organization demonstrate against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Nicole Buchanan/The New York Times)

Amy Ratanapakdee lights incense for her father Vicha, who died as a result of injuries from an attack at the Nagara Dhamma Temple in San Francisco, Feb. 22, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

A ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

column3: COVID-19/coronavirus/pandemic (Triggering anti-Asian hate)
column4: The article references racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump and other public officials, which have fueled discrimination against Asian Americans ('fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump').
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "COVID-19/coronavirus/pandemic (Triggering anti-Asian hate)" is relevant to the article, but its fit is not as strong or comprehensive as it could be given the article's broader focus. Let's evaluate it based on the criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it mentions the coronavirus and its connection to anti-Asian discrimination. However, this is not the primary focus of the article, which deals more broadly with the long-standing issue of anti-Asian racism and the recent surge in violence.

2. Specificity: The concept is specific enough to capture one aspect of the article, but it doesn't encompass the broader historical and societal issues discussed. The article goes beyond just COVID-19-related discrimination to explore systemic racism, historical context, and current activism.

3. Coverage: The chosen concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. While the pandemic is mentioned as a contributing factor, the article spends more time discussing the Atlanta shootings, historical discrimination, and the broader context of anti-Asian racism in America.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects a part of the information presented in the article, particularly the reference to Trump's use of racist language related to the coronavirus. However, it doesn't capture the full scope of the article's discussion on anti-Asian discrimination.

5. Insight: While the concept provides some insight into one trigger for recent anti-Asian sentiment, it doesn't offer a comprehensive framework for understanding the article's main themes of long-standing discrimination, recent violence, and calls for action.

The explanation provided focuses on a single sentence in the article that mentions Trump's coronavirus rhetoric. While this is accurate, it doesn't reflect the article's broader scope, which includes historical context (e.g., the Chinese Exclusion Act, Japanese internment), recent violent incidents (the Atlanta shootings), and the ongoing struggle for recognition of anti-Asian racism as a serious issue.

A more fitting concept might be something broader like "Types of Anti-Asian hate" or "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate," as these would encompass more of the article's content, including both historical and contemporary issues, as well as community responses and calls for action.
</reasoning>

5
</score>
</evaluation>

column1:
After Georgia Attacks Asian Americans Demand Serious Action on Bias

Eligon John, Fuller Thomas, Cowan Jill

New York Times

2021-03-18

Police officers mingle with demonstrators at a ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)
Video clips of disturbing attacks on the street. Insults hurled by politicians. Derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses.
For most of the last year, Asian Americans have sounded the alarm over the rising discrimination they have experienced and witnessed fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump and other public officials. Celebrities, activists, and influencers on social media have implored people to stop the hate against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders.
Then came the fatal shootings in Georgia of eight people, six of them women of Asian descent.
Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the carnage has evoked another emotion among some Asian Americans: anger over the country’s long-standing failure to take discrimination against them seriously.
Some scholars and activists said Tuesday’s massacre was unsurprising after public officials and popular culture have for years downplayed the dangers of bias and stereotypes against Asians.
Although Asian Americans, like other minority groups, have endured a long history of deadly violence, the threats and discrimination they continue to face are often trivialized as harmless insults. In many cases, some said, people are reluctant to even acknowledge that attacks against Asian Americans could be racially motivated, as happened Wednesday when a law enforcement official in Georgia seemed to dismiss racial animus as a motive in the shootings.
Instead, he said the suspect, Robert Aaron Long, who is white, was having “a really bad day” and cited Long’s statement that he was driven by a sex addiction and not racial bias.
Even when anti-Asian violence is acknowledged, experts say it is sometimes casually dismissed as an isolated episode rather than a core part of the Asian American story.
“There’s a tendency to not believe that violence against Asian Americans is real,” said Angela Hsu, 52, a lawyer in suburban Atlanta. “It’s almost like you need something really, really jarring to make people believe that there is discrimination against Asian Americans.”
Without a deeper, widespread understanding of, or belief in the dangers that Asian Americans face, it’s difficult for activists to marshal a concerted national push — in law enforcement, the media, and the public — to fight anti-Asian racism, activists say.
They tend to be invisible to much of society, which only furthers a widespread dismissal of anti-Asian violence, said Chris J. Lee, 33, a founder of Plan A Magazine, an online journal focused on Asian American culture and politics.
“The types of people who get killed, like people who work at massage parlors, elderly Asians picking up cans for a living — none of us really know these people,” he said.
The marginalization of Asian Americans has deep roots.
Chinese immigrants who built railways and mined gold in the 19th century were shunted into Chinatowns in San Francisco and other cities, redlined by financial institutions and often left to fend for themselves.
Further immigration from China was restricted by the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the first immigration law targeting working-class immigrants from a specific country. It was followed in 1917 by the most restrictive immigration law in the nation’s history, the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, which blocked immigrants from Istanbul all the way to Jakarta and beyond, nearly eliminating all arrivals from some of the most populous areas of the planet — the South Asian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.
Japanese residents in the United States were for decades kept out of white neighborhoods through covenants written into real estate deeds; tens of thousands of American citizens of Japanese descent were incarcerated in internment camps during World War II.
When immigration laws were liberalized in the 1960s, immigrants from Asia were allowed into the U.S. in unprecedented numbers. 
Asian ethnic groups, though distinct from one another, have at times been lumped together under the umbrella of an Asian American identity. But the anti-Asian violence that has come during the pandemic seems to have solidified a greater sense of solidarity among a group that is diverse in income, religion, and culture, said Will Lex Ham, an actor who has helped lead a campaign of awareness of violence against Asians.
“As long as we share the same physical features, we are being treated the same in this country,” Ham said.
In the wake of attacks on older people in Asian neighborhoods in California, some community leaders have demanded an increased police presence. Others have said that simply adding law enforcement officers was not a solution.
Some are pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to appoint an Asian American to be California’s attorney general.
An Asian American as the state’s top law enforcement official is needed to build trust “particularly when it comes to what have been strained relationships between law enforcement and immigrant communities and communities of color,” David Chiu, a member of the California state Assembly, said during a news conference Wednesday.
In the Atlanta area, where the Asian community has grown in recent years and become more politically influential, the murders have reignited anxieties that may have been subsiding for some people as an end to the pandemic is in sight. When the pandemic began, Hsu, the lawyer, said she almost expected that people would hurl insults at her because she is Chinese American. In recent weeks, she had let her guard down, she said.
“We’re coming out of the pandemic, there’s a new president, we’re not hearing ‘Kung Flu’ and ‘China Virus’ every other word,” she said, referring to some of the derogatory terms that Trump used for the coronavirus. “I was really lured into thinking it’s sort of safe to go outside again.” 
Now she is back on high alert.
Suraiya Sharker, a community organizer with the Atlanta chapter of the National Asian Pacific American Women’s Forum, said that after the shootings, she received calls from several members of her organization who were in tears.
Sharker, 22, is particularly worried about her parents, who moved to the United States from Bangladesh when she was 4, because they are of the demographic particularly vulnerable to attacks. As first-generation immigrants, their English is not perfect. They work in a fast-food restaurant in suburban Atlanta where Sharker said a customer once threatened her father in a disagreement over the bill and customers have refused to be served by her mother because she wears a hijab.
But as much as she and other Asian Americans are more cautious now, they are also more energized, she said.
“This,” she said, “has been an awakening for a lot of folks to say ‘Enough is enough.’”

A woman leaves flowers at a memorial outside of Gold Spa in Atlanta following the mass shooting there, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Lynsey Weatherspoon/The New York Times)

Brittany Tabora and Ina Padua participate in a demonstration against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Shuran Huang/The New York Times)

Members of a progressive youth organization demonstrate against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Nicole Buchanan/The New York Times)

Amy Ratanapakdee lights incense for her father Vicha, who died as a result of injuries from an attack at the Nagara Dhamma Temple in San Francisco, Feb. 22, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

A ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it discusses anti-Asian hate and mentions specific derogatory terms used to refer to the coronavirus. However, this is not the main focus of the article, which more broadly covers the rise in discrimination and violence against Asian Americans, particularly in light of the Atlanta shootings.

2. Specificity: The chosen concept is quite specific, focusing on particular derogatory terms used to describe the virus. While this specificity is accurate for the brief mention in the article, it doesn't capture the broader themes of anti-Asian discrimination and violence discussed throughout.

3. Coverage: The concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. The article touches on many aspects of anti-Asian hate, including historical context, recent violent incidents, community responses, and the broader impact on Asian Americans. The specific terms mentioned in the concept are only briefly referenced in one paragraph.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects the information presented in the article regarding the use of derogatory terms by former President Trump. However, it doesn't capture the full scope of anti-Asian sentiment and actions described in the article.

5. Insight: While the concept provides some insight into one aspect of anti-Asian hate (the use of derogatory language), it doesn't offer a comprehensive framework for understanding the article's main themes, such as the long-standing nature of anti-Asian discrimination, the recent surge in violence, and the community's response.

The explanation provided for choosing this concept is accurate but limited. It correctly identifies the mention of "Kung Flu" and "China Virus" in the article, but it doesn't address how these terms fit into the broader context of the article's discussion on anti-Asian hate and discrimination.

A more fitting concept from the tree might be "Types of Anti-Asian hate" or "Individual-level racism" as a whole, as these broader categories would encompass more of the article's content, including the violent incidents, stereotypes, and various forms of discrimination discussed.

column4: The overall theme of the article discusses the xenophobia experienced by Asian Americans, especially in the context of the pandemic ('rising discrimination they have experienced and witnessed fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus').
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "Types of Anti-Asian hate/Individual-level racism/Bigotry/prejudice/Xenophobia" is a good fit for the article, but it doesn't capture the full scope of the content. Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is highly relevant to the main themes of the article. The article focuses on the discrimination and violence faced by Asian Americans, which is a clear manifestation of xenophobia and individual-level racism. The article mentions "rising discrimination" and "racist language," which align well with the chosen concept.

2. Specificity: The concept is at an appropriate level of specificity. It correctly identifies the type of racism (individual-level) and the specific form of prejudice (xenophobia) that is prevalent in the situations described in the article. However, it doesn't capture some of the more specific aspects discussed, such as the historical context of discrimination against Asian Americans.

3. Coverage: While the concept covers a significant portion of the article's content, it doesn't encompass everything. The article goes beyond just describing xenophobia; it also discusses systemic issues, historical context, and the community's response to discrimination. For example, the article mentions the Chinese Exclusion Act and the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, which are more related to systemic racism than individual-level xenophobia.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects much of the information presented in the article. The examples of discrimination and violence described in the article, such as "Insults hurled by politicians" and "Derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses," fit well within the framework of individual-level racism and xenophobia.

5. Insight: The concept provides a meaningful way to understand a significant portion of the article's content. It correctly identifies that the discrimination described is primarily driven by individual-level prejudice and xenophobia. However, it misses some of the broader insights the article offers, such as the historical context of discrimination against Asian Americans and the community's response to recent events.

While the chosen concept is a good fit, it doesn't fully capture the article's discussion of systemic issues, historical context, and community responses. The article goes beyond just describing xenophobia to explore the broader landscape of discrimination against Asian Americans, including both historical and contemporary aspects. The concept also doesn't reflect the article's focus on the Atlanta shootings and the community's reaction to this event, which forms a significant part of the narrative.

</reasoning>

column1:
After Georgia Attacks Asian Americans Demand Serious Action on Bias

Eligon John, Fuller Thomas, Cowan Jill

New York Times

2021-03-18

Police officers mingle with demonstrators at a ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)
Video clips of disturbing attacks on the street. Insults hurled by politicians. Derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses.
For most of the last year, Asian Americans have sounded the alarm over the rising discrimination they have experienced and witnessed fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump and other public officials. Celebrities, activists, and influencers on social media have implored people to stop the hate against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders.
Then came the fatal shootings in Georgia of eight people, six of them women of Asian descent.
Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the carnage has evoked another emotion among some Asian Americans: anger over the country’s long-standing failure to take discrimination against them seriously.
Some scholars and activists said Tuesday’s massacre was unsurprising after public officials and popular culture have for years downplayed the dangers of bias and stereotypes against Asians.
Although Asian Americans, like other minority groups, have endured a long history of deadly violence, the threats and discrimination they continue to face are often trivialized as harmless insults. In many cases, some said, people are reluctant to even acknowledge that attacks against Asian Americans could be racially motivated, as happened Wednesday when a law enforcement official in Georgia seemed to dismiss racial animus as a motive in the shootings.
Instead, he said the suspect, Robert Aaron Long, who is white, was having “a really bad day” and cited Long’s statement that he was driven by a sex addiction and not racial bias.
Even when anti-Asian violence is acknowledged, experts say it is sometimes casually dismissed as an isolated episode rather than a core part of the Asian American story.
“There’s a tendency to not believe that violence against Asian Americans is real,” said Angela Hsu, 52, a lawyer in suburban Atlanta. “It’s almost like you need something really, really jarring to make people believe that there is discrimination against Asian Americans.”
Without a deeper, widespread understanding of, or belief in the dangers that Asian Americans face, it’s difficult for activists to marshal a concerted national push — in law enforcement, the media, and the public — to fight anti-Asian racism, activists say.
They tend to be invisible to much of society, which only furthers a widespread dismissal of anti-Asian violence, said Chris J. Lee, 33, a founder of Plan A Magazine, an online journal focused on Asian American culture and politics.
“The types of people who get killed, like people who work at massage parlors, elderly Asians picking up cans for a living — none of us really know these people,” he said.
The marginalization of Asian Americans has deep roots.
Chinese immigrants who built railways and mined gold in the 19th century were shunted into Chinatowns in San Francisco and other cities, redlined by financial institutions and often left to fend for themselves.
Further immigration from China was restricted by the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the first immigration law targeting working-class immigrants from a specific country. It was followed in 1917 by the most restrictive immigration law in the nation’s history, the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, which blocked immigrants from Istanbul all the way to Jakarta and beyond, nearly eliminating all arrivals from some of the most populous areas of the planet — the South Asian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.
Japanese residents in the United States were for decades kept out of white neighborhoods through covenants written into real estate deeds; tens of thousands of American citizens of Japanese descent were incarcerated in internment camps during World War II.
When immigration laws were liberalized in the 1960s, immigrants from Asia were allowed into the U.S. in unprecedented numbers. 
Asian ethnic groups, though distinct from one another, have at times been lumped together under the umbrella of an Asian American identity. But the anti-Asian violence that has come during the pandemic seems to have solidified a greater sense of solidarity among a group that is diverse in income, religion, and culture, said Will Lex Ham, an actor who has helped lead a campaign of awareness of violence against Asians.
“As long as we share the same physical features, we are being treated the same in this country,” Ham said.
In the wake of attacks on older people in Asian neighborhoods in California, some community leaders have demanded an increased police presence. Others have said that simply adding law enforcement officers was not a solution.
Some are pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to appoint an Asian American to be California’s attorney general.
An Asian American as the state’s top law enforcement official is needed to build trust “particularly when it comes to what have been strained relationships between law enforcement and immigrant communities and communities of color,” David Chiu, a member of the California state Assembly, said during a news conference Wednesday.
In the Atlanta area, where the Asian community has grown in recent years and become more politically influential, the murders have reignited anxieties that may have been subsiding for some people as an end to the pandemic is in sight. When the pandemic began, Hsu, the lawyer, said she almost expected that people would hurl insults at her because she is Chinese American. In recent weeks, she had let her guard down, she said.
“We’re coming out of the pandemic, there’s a new president, we’re not hearing ‘Kung Flu’ and ‘China Virus’ every other word,” she said, referring to some of the derogatory terms that Trump used for the coronavirus. “I was really lured into thinking it’s sort of safe to go outside again.” 
Now she is back on high alert.
Suraiya Sharker, a community organizer with the Atlanta chapter of the National Asian Pacific American Women’s Forum, said that after the shootings, she received calls from several members of her organization who were in tears.
Sharker, 22, is particularly worried about her parents, who moved to the United States from Bangladesh when she was 4, because they are of the demographic particularly vulnerable to attacks. As first-generation immigrants, their English is not perfect. They work in a fast-food restaurant in suburban Atlanta where Sharker said a customer once threatened her father in a disagreement over the bill and customers have refused to be served by her mother because she wears a hijab.
But as much as she and other Asian Americans are more cautious now, they are also more energized, she said.
“This,” she said, “has been an awakening for a lot of folks to say ‘Enough is enough.’”

A woman leaves flowers at a memorial outside of Gold Spa in Atlanta following the mass shooting there, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Lynsey Weatherspoon/The New York Times)

Brittany Tabora and Ina Padua participate in a demonstration against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Shuran Huang/The New York Times)

Members of a progressive youth organization demonstrate against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Nicole Buchanan/The New York Times)

Amy Ratanapakdee lights incense for her father Vicha, who died as a result of injuries from an attack at the Nagara Dhamma Temple in San Francisco, Feb. 22, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

A ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

1. Relevance: The concept is highly relevant to the main topic of the article, which focuses on the Atlanta shootings and the broader context of anti-Asian hate crimes. The article extensively discusses the attack and its impact on the Asian American community.

2. Specificity: The concept is quite specific, which is both a strength and a limitation. It accurately captures the nature of the Atlanta shootings as an anti-Asian hate crime committed by a white individual. However, this specificity means it doesn't encompass the broader discussions in the article about historical discrimination and other forms of anti-Asian bias.

3. Coverage: While the concept covers a crucial aspect of the article, it doesn't encompass the full range of topics discussed. The article goes beyond just describing the attack to explore historical context, community reactions, and broader issues of discrimination against Asian Americans.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects the information about the Atlanta shootings presented in the article. However, it's worth noting that the article mentions some ambiguity about the motive, with a law enforcement official initially seeming to "dismiss racial animus as a motive in the shootings."

5. Insight: The concept provides a meaningful way to categorize the central event discussed in the article. However, it doesn't capture the article's insights into the broader patterns of discrimination and the community's response to the attack.

The explanation provided for choosing this concept is accurate but limited. While it correctly identifies the Atlanta shootings as an example of an anti-Asian hate crime investigated by police with a white perpetrator, it doesn't address the article's broader focus on the historical context of anti-Asian discrimination and the community's response to the attack.

The concept fits well for the specific incident described but doesn't capture the article's wider exploration of anti-Asian sentiment, historical discrimination, and community reactions. The article discusses various forms of discrimination beyond just violent attacks, including "insults hurled by politicians" and "derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses," which aren't captured by this specific concept.

column4: The article suggests that the Atlanta shooter was driven by a sex addiction, leading to racially motivated sexual violence against Asian women ('sex addiction and not racial bias').
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "Types of Anti-Asian hate/Individual-level racism/Racial discrimination/Physical attack/violence/Anti-Asian hate crimes (investigated by police)/sexual violence" has some relevance to the article, but it doesn't fully capture the main themes and complexities presented. Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is relevant to the article, as it discusses the shootings in Atlanta that targeted Asian women. However, the article covers a much broader range of issues related to anti-Asian discrimination and violence.

2. Specificity: The concept is quite specific, focusing on sexual violence as an anti-Asian hate crime. While this aspect is mentioned in the article, it's not the primary focus.

3. Coverage: The chosen concept covers only a small portion of the article's content. The article discusses historical context, various forms of discrimination, community responses, and broader societal issues beyond just the sexual violence aspect of the Atlanta shootings.

4. Accuracy: The concept is not entirely accurate in representing the article's content. While the article mentions the suspect's claim of sex addiction, it also emphasizes that many Asian Americans view the attack as racially motivated, contrary to the official statement that dismissed racial animus.

5. Insight: The concept provides limited insight into the article's main themes. It focuses on one specific aspect (sexual violence) while missing the broader discussion on systemic racism, historical context, and the complexities of Asian American experiences.

The explanation provided with the chosen concept oversimplifies the article's content. While the article does mention the sex addiction claim, it presents this as a controversial statement that many Asian Americans disagree with. The article emphasizes the anger and frustration within the Asian American community over the long-standing dismissal of anti-Asian discrimination.

A more fitting concept might be one that encompasses the broader themes of anti-Asian discrimination, historical context, and the community's response to violence. For example, a concept like "Types of Anti-Asian hate/Macro-level racism/systematic racism/racial injustice/inequity and oppression" combined with elements from "Reactions toward Anti-Asian Hate" would better capture the article's main focus on the systemic nature of anti-Asian discrimination and the community's demand for serious action.

</reasoning>

<score>
4
</score>
</evaluation>

column1:
After Georgia Attacks Asian Americans Demand Serious Action on Bias

Eligon John, Fuller Thomas, Cowan Jill

New York Times

2021-03-18

Police officers mingle with demonstrators at a ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)
Video clips of disturbing attacks on the street. Insults hurled by politicians. Derogatory graffiti scrawled on businesses.
For most of the last year, Asian Americans have sounded the alarm over the rising discrimination they have experienced and witnessed fueled in part by racist language and false claims about the coronavirus by former President Donald Trump and other public officials. Celebrities, activists, and influencers on social media have implored people to stop the hate against Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders.
Then came the fatal shootings in Georgia of eight people, six of them women of Asian descent.
Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the carnage has evoked another emotion among some Asian Americans: anger over the country’s long-standing failure to take discrimination against them seriously.
Some scholars and activists said Tuesday’s massacre was unsurprising after public officials and popular culture have for years downplayed the dangers of bias and stereotypes against Asians.
Although Asian Americans, like other minority groups, have endured a long history of deadly violence, the threats and discrimination they continue to face are often trivialized as harmless insults. In many cases, some said, people are reluctant to even acknowledge that attacks against Asian Americans could be racially motivated, as happened Wednesday when a law enforcement official in Georgia seemed to dismiss racial animus as a motive in the shootings.
Instead, he said the suspect, Robert Aaron Long, who is white, was having “a really bad day” and cited Long’s statement that he was driven by a sex addiction and not racial bias.
Even when anti-Asian violence is acknowledged, experts say it is sometimes casually dismissed as an isolated episode rather than a core part of the Asian American story.
“There’s a tendency to not believe that violence against Asian Americans is real,” said Angela Hsu, 52, a lawyer in suburban Atlanta. “It’s almost like you need something really, really jarring to make people believe that there is discrimination against Asian Americans.”
Without a deeper, widespread understanding of, or belief in the dangers that Asian Americans face, it’s difficult for activists to marshal a concerted national push — in law enforcement, the media, and the public — to fight anti-Asian racism, activists say.
They tend to be invisible to much of society, which only furthers a widespread dismissal of anti-Asian violence, said Chris J. Lee, 33, a founder of Plan A Magazine, an online journal focused on Asian American culture and politics.
“The types of people who get killed, like people who work at massage parlors, elderly Asians picking up cans for a living — none of us really know these people,” he said.
The marginalization of Asian Americans has deep roots.
Chinese immigrants who built railways and mined gold in the 19th century were shunted into Chinatowns in San Francisco and other cities, redlined by financial institutions and often left to fend for themselves.
Further immigration from China was restricted by the Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, the first immigration law targeting working-class immigrants from a specific country. It was followed in 1917 by the most restrictive immigration law in the nation’s history, the Asiatic Barred Zone Act, which blocked immigrants from Istanbul all the way to Jakarta and beyond, nearly eliminating all arrivals from some of the most populous areas of the planet — the South Asian subcontinent and Southeast Asia.
Japanese residents in the United States were for decades kept out of white neighborhoods through covenants written into real estate deeds; tens of thousands of American citizens of Japanese descent were incarcerated in internment camps during World War II.
When immigration laws were liberalized in the 1960s, immigrants from Asia were allowed into the U.S. in unprecedented numbers. 
Asian ethnic groups, though distinct from one another, have at times been lumped together under the umbrella of an Asian American identity. But the anti-Asian violence that has come during the pandemic seems to have solidified a greater sense of solidarity among a group that is diverse in income, religion, and culture, said Will Lex Ham, an actor who has helped lead a campaign of awareness of violence against Asians.
“As long as we share the same physical features, we are being treated the same in this country,” Ham said.
In the wake of attacks on older people in Asian neighborhoods in California, some community leaders have demanded an increased police presence. Others have said that simply adding law enforcement officers was not a solution.
Some are pushing Gov. Gavin Newsom to appoint an Asian American to be California’s attorney general.
An Asian American as the state’s top law enforcement official is needed to build trust “particularly when it comes to what have been strained relationships between law enforcement and immigrant communities and communities of color,” David Chiu, a member of the California state Assembly, said during a news conference Wednesday.
In the Atlanta area, where the Asian community has grown in recent years and become more politically influential, the murders have reignited anxieties that may have been subsiding for some people as an end to the pandemic is in sight. When the pandemic began, Hsu, the lawyer, said she almost expected that people would hurl insults at her because she is Chinese American. In recent weeks, she had let her guard down, she said.
“We’re coming out of the pandemic, there’s a new president, we’re not hearing ‘Kung Flu’ and ‘China Virus’ every other word,” she said, referring to some of the derogatory terms that Trump used for the coronavirus. “I was really lured into thinking it’s sort of safe to go outside again.” 
Now she is back on high alert.
Suraiya Sharker, a community organizer with the Atlanta chapter of the National Asian Pacific American Women’s Forum, said that after the shootings, she received calls from several members of her organization who were in tears.
Sharker, 22, is particularly worried about her parents, who moved to the United States from Bangladesh when she was 4, because they are of the demographic particularly vulnerable to attacks. As first-generation immigrants, their English is not perfect. They work in a fast-food restaurant in suburban Atlanta where Sharker said a customer once threatened her father in a disagreement over the bill and customers have refused to be served by her mother because she wears a hijab.
But as much as she and other Asian Americans are more cautious now, they are also more energized, she said.
“This,” she said, “has been an awakening for a lot of folks to say ‘Enough is enough.’”

A woman leaves flowers at a memorial outside of Gold Spa in Atlanta following the mass shooting there, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Lynsey Weatherspoon/The New York Times)

Brittany Tabora and Ina Padua participate in a demonstration against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Shuran Huang/The New York Times)

Members of a progressive youth organization demonstrate against violence targeting Asian Americans in Washington, March 17, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Nicole Buchanan/The New York Times)

Amy Ratanapakdee lights incense for her father Vicha, who died as a result of injuries from an attack at the Nagara Dhamma Temple in San Francisco, Feb. 22, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Jim Wilson/The New York Times)

A ‘Stop Asian Hate’ rally in the Seattle suburb of Bellevue Thursday, March 18, 2021. Amid fear, sadness, and pain, the shootings in the Atlanta area have generated anger over the country’s longstanding failure to address anti-Asian discrimination. (Ruth Fremson/The New York Times)

column3: Impacts of Anti-Asian hate on Asian Americans/Psychological/mental health/PTSD/negative emotions
column4: The shootings and ongoing discrimination have caused fear, sadness, and pain among Asian Americans, contributing to mental health issues ('Amid fear, sadness, and pain').
column5:
<evaluation>
<reasoning>
The chosen concept "Impacts of Anti-Asian hate on Asian Americans/Psychological/mental health/PTSD/negative emotions" is a reasonably good fit for the article, but it doesn't fully capture the breadth of the content. Let's evaluate it based on the given criteria:

1. Relevance: The concept is highly relevant to the article. The piece discusses the psychological impact of anti-Asian hate crimes, particularly in light of the recent shootings in Georgia. The article mentions "fear, sadness, and pain" multiple times, which aligns with the "negative emotions" part of the chosen concept.

2. Specificity: The concept is appropriately specific, focusing on the psychological impacts of anti-Asian hate. However, it may be slightly too specific in mentioning PTSD, which isn't explicitly discussed in the article. The broader category of "mental health" and "negative emotions" is more directly applicable.

3. Coverage: While the concept covers an important aspect of the article, it doesn't encompass the full range of topics discussed. The article also covers historical context, current activism, political responses, and the broader societal issue of discrimination against Asian Americans. The psychological impact is just one part of this larger narrative.

4. Accuracy: The concept accurately reflects some of the information in the article, particularly the emotional responses of Asian Americans to the recent violence and ongoing discrimination. For example, the article mentions that community members were "in tears" and feeling "fear, sadness, and pain."

5. Insight: The concept provides a meaningful way to understand one aspect of the article's content, highlighting the personal, emotional toll of anti-Asian hate. However, it doesn't capture the article's broader themes of societal neglect, historical context, and calls for action.

The explanation provided is accurate but limited. It correctly identifies that the shootings and discrimination have caused negative emotions among Asian Americans. However, it doesn't fully capture the anger and frustration expressed in the article about the "long-standing failure to take discrimination against them seriously."

While the chosen concept is relevant and accurate for a portion of the article, it misses significant aspects of the piece. The article is more focused on the societal response (or lack thereof) to anti-Asian discrimination and the push for greater recognition and action. The psychological impact, while present, is not the primary focus of the article.
</reasoning>

<score>
6
</score>
</evaluation>
